Federated Reinforcement Learning at the Edge

Konstantinos Gatsis The author is with the Department of Engineering Science, University of Oxford, Parks Road, Oxford, OX1 3PJ, UK. Email: konstantinos.gatsis@eng.ox.ac.uk.
Abstract

Modern cyber-physical architectures use data collected from systems at different physical locations to learn appropriate behaviors and adapt to uncertain environments. However, an important challenge arises as communication exchanges at the edge of networked systems are costly due to limited resources. This paper considers a setup where multiple agents need to communicate efficiently in order to jointly solve a reinforcement learning problem over time-series data collected in a distributed manner. This is posed as learning an approximate value function over a communication network. An algorithm for achieving communication efficiency is proposed, supported with theoretical guarantees, practical implementations, and numerical evaluations. The approach is based on the idea of communicating only when sufficiently informative data is collected.

I Introduction

Recent years have seen a shift in cyber-physical system architectures from systems running in isolation or local networks to systems connected to the cloud for outsourcing data and computations. This has given rise to the realization that the resulting bandwidth and communication requirements can become a bottleneck, and as a result, computing at the edge of the architecture is explored. Learning and adapting to data from sensors, robots, or vehicles located at the edge enable new applications such as cloud robotics [1], connected autonomous transportation systems, and the Industrial Internet-of-Things. Toward this end, this paper introduces a new framework for performing distributed reinforcement learning from data collected locally at individual agents/robots at the edge.

The accelerating developments in machine learning and reinforcement learning have increased the interest of the control community in using data-driven techniques. Specifically in the area of control of distributed and multi-agent systems, very recent developments include algorithms for multi-agent reinforcement learning [2, 3, 4], reinforcement learning over networks/graphs [5, 6, 7, 8], as well as the search for appropriate parameterizations for these problems [9]. However when dealing with distributed learning at the edge, there is also the need for communication efficiency, especially if agents have high dimensional time-series data and operate over resource-limited communication networks.

The bulk of research in the area of distributed and communication-efficient learning, also termed federated learning, is focused on static machine learning problems, such as classification. To overcome the communication bottleneck of sending high dimensional data, the main idea is to send gradients of the objective with respect to the parameters being learned, instead of the data itself. Approaches based on gradient quantization and non-periodic updates [10, 11, 12], allocation of wireless resources [13, 14], or approaches exploiting the informativeness of the data [15, 16] are being explored. For the problem of communication-efficient reinforcement learning, only now initial approaches emerge, including non-periodic updates for policy gradient methods [17], distributed peer-to-peer network architectures [18], specific problems such as multi-armed bandits [19], or regret analysis of online distributed reinforcement learning [20].

This paper introduces a new approach for communication-efficient reinforcement learning problems. To avoid costly exchange of time-series data, agents should assess how informative are the data they collect, and communicate if the update will help the process of learning. The setup, described in Section II and shown in Fig. 1, involves multiple agents collecting state transitions and costs in a distributed manner for the purpose of learning approximate value functions, which is a central problem in reinforcement learning. Specifically linear value function approximation is considered. While all recent approaches [17, 18, 19, 20] try to limit the amount of communication exchange during reinforcement learning, the main novelty of this paper is that the communication cost is part of the performance criterion, and the resulting advantage is that algorithms which by design efficiently tradeoff communication and learning are developed. This is obtained both theoretically (Section III) as well as in numerical examples in finite and continuous state spaces (Section V).

The approach adapts ideas from the author’s recent work on communication-efficient linear regression [15, 16] to the reinforcement learning problem. On the technical side, the approach is different here as, to ensure convergence close to an optimal solution, the agents increasingly send less informative data as the number of iterations of the learning algorithm grows. More broadly, the technical methodology relates to the problem of efficient control over networks [21, 22], event-triggered learning [23, 24] and resource-aware optimization [25, 26, 27, 28].

II Problem Setup

The architecture examined in this paper, shown in Fig. 1, involves an access-point/server interested in solving a reinforcement learning task on data that are collected by multiple agents. Specifically, each agent is collecting independently state transitions (from a state xtsuperscript𝑥𝑡x^{t} to a new state x+tsubscriptsuperscript𝑥𝑡x^{t}_{+}) and cost measurements (of the form ctsuperscript𝑐𝑡c^{t} at state xtsuperscript𝑥𝑡x^{t}), and communicate with the server in order to jointly learn an approximate value function V​(x)𝑉𝑥V(x) parameterized by a vector of weights w𝑤w. The aim will be to achieve this with communication efficiency, i.e., without agents communicating all collected data all the time. An example scenario is presented, and the formal mathematical formulation follows next.

Example 1 (Motivating scenarios).

As a first example, suppose the agents in Fig. 1 are robots/drones/vehicles with identical system dynamics. Then they can each collect data from their own trajectories (state transitions) as well as costs measuring how well they can achieve a common task, such as tracking a desired behavior. Transmitting all these data over the communication network would be costly. A recent case study of this form by Google [29] considers the large scale training of control and manipulation policies using multiple robots collecting image data concurrently. As a second example, suppose the agents in Fig. 1 are sensors/actuators in an industrial setting collecting time-series data from multiple identical physical processes, for the purpose of improving the control of the processes.

II-A Mathematical Problem Formulation

We assume a Markov Decision Process problem defined by the state space X𝑋X, the action space A𝐴A, the transition probabilities ℙ​(x+|x,a)ℙconditionalsubscript𝑥𝑥𝑎\mathbb{P}(x_{+}{\,\big{|}\,}x,a)111or alternatively general state dynamics of the form x+=f​(x,a,w)subscript𝑥𝑓𝑥𝑎𝑤x_{+}=f(x,a,w) for some noise variable w𝑤w, and a cost function c:X×A→ℝ:𝑐→𝑋𝐴ℝc:X\times A\rightarrow{\mathbb{R}} giving rise to costs of the form ck=c​(xk,ak)subscript𝑐𝑘𝑐subscript𝑥𝑘subscript𝑎𝑘c_{k}=c(x_{k},a_{k}). We are interested in approximating the value function, or cost-to-go function of a given policy ak=π​(xk)subscript𝑎𝑘𝜋subscript𝑥𝑘a_{k}=\pi(x_{k}), defined as V​(x):=𝔼​[∑k=0∞γk​c​(xk,ak)|x0=x]assign𝑉𝑥𝔼delimited-[]conditionalsuperscriptsubscript𝑘0superscript𝛾𝑘𝑐subscript𝑥𝑘subscript𝑎𝑘subscript𝑥0𝑥V(x):=\mathbb{E}\left[\sum_{k=0}^{\infty}\gamma^{k}c(x_{k},a_{k}){\,\big{|}\,}x_{0}=x\right] with a discount factor γ∈(0,1)𝛾01\gamma\in(0,1). A general theoretical approach for finding the value function is to perform the Value Iteration Algorithm, which iteratively fixes a current guess of the value function Vcurrent​(x),x∈Xsuperscript𝑉current𝑥𝑥𝑋V^{\text{current}}(x),x\in X, and updates it according to

Vupdated​(x)superscript𝑉updated𝑥\displaystyle V^{\text{updated}}(x) =c​(x,π​(x))absent𝑐𝑥𝜋𝑥\displaystyle=c(x,\pi(x))
+γ​𝔼​[Vcurrent​(x+)|x,a=π​(x)]𝛾𝔼delimited-[]conditionalsuperscript𝑉currentsubscript𝑥𝑥𝑎𝜋𝑥\displaystyle+\gamma\,\mathbb{E}[V^{\text{current}}(x_{+}){\,\big{|}\,}x,a=\pi(x)] (1)

for all points x∈X𝑥𝑋x\in X, and repeats the process again and again. Under technical conditions[30, Vol. II, Ch. 2], this process can converge to the desired value function V​(x)𝑉𝑥V(x), which is a fixed point of II-A (Bellman equation).

In reinforcement learning and approximate dynamic programming, this iteration is performed approximately, using data collected by following the given policy. The data consists of multiple state transitions from states xt,t=0,1,2,…formulae-sequencesuperscript𝑥𝑡𝑡012…x^{t},t=0,1,2,\ldots to new states x+t,t=0,1,2,…formulae-sequencesubscriptsuperscript𝑥𝑡𝑡012…x^{t}_{+},t=0,1,2,\ldots, following the above transition probabilities, and stage costs of the form ctsuperscript𝑐𝑡c^{t} at state xt,t=0,1,2,…formulae-sequencesuperscript𝑥𝑡𝑡012…x^{t},t=0,1,2,\ldots. In general we can denote these as tuples (xt,ct,x+t),t=0,1,2,…formulae-sequencesuperscript𝑥𝑡superscript𝑐𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑥𝑡𝑡012…(x^{t},c^{t},x_{+}^{t}),t=0,1,2,\ldots. In practice, these state transitions can be just segments from longer state trajectories. The state samples xt,t=0,1,2,…formulae-sequencesuperscript𝑥𝑡𝑡012…x^{t},t=0,1,2,\ldots are modeled as drawn from a distribution d​(x)𝑑𝑥d(x) in this paper.

Moreover, instead of computing the updated value function in II-A in the space of all functions {V:X→ℝ}conditional-set𝑉→𝑋ℝ\{V:X\rightarrow{\mathbb{R}}\}, a restricted function class is selected. In this paper we follow the commonly employed linear function class [31, 30]. In other words, we are trying to explain Vupdated​(x)superscript𝑉updated𝑥V^{\text{updated}}(x) in II-A as a linear combination of basis functions (features) as

Vupdated​(x)≈∑i=1nwi​ϕi​(x).superscript𝑉updated𝑥superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛subscript𝑤𝑖subscriptitalic-ϕ𝑖𝑥V^{\text{updated}}(x)\approx\sum_{i=1}^{n}w_{i}\phi_{i}(x). (2)

Here w∈ℝn𝑤superscriptℝ𝑛w\in{\mathbb{R}}^{n} if the vector of weights (linear combination) to be learned, consisting of elements wisubscript𝑤𝑖w_{i}, and ϕi​(x)subscriptitalic-ϕ𝑖𝑥\phi_{i}(x) are fixed basis functions (not learned). Examples of general basis functions, especially when X𝑋X is a real vector space, include discretization functions, polynomial functions, radial basis functions, and others [31, 30].

To pick one particular approximation in 2, we are interested in minimizing the squared error

minimizew∈ℝn​J​(w)=𝔼d​[Vupdated​(x)−∑i=1nwi​ϕi​(x)]2𝑤superscriptℝ𝑛minimize𝐽𝑤subscript𝔼𝑑superscriptdelimited-[]superscript𝑉updated𝑥superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛subscript𝑤𝑖subscriptitalic-ϕ𝑖𝑥2\underset{w\in{\mathbb{R}}^{n}}{\text{minimize}}\;J(w)=\mathbb{E}_{d}\left[V^{\text{updated}}(x)-\sum_{i=1}^{n}w_{i}\phi_{i}(x)\right]^{2} (3)

where the expectation is with respect to a distribution d​(x)𝑑𝑥d(x), which corresponds to the distribution of the data collected by the agents. To sum up, instead of updating the value function according to II-A, we instead approximately update to the function ∑i=1nwi∗​ϕi​(x)superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛subscriptsuperscript𝑤𝑖subscriptitalic-ϕ𝑖𝑥\sum_{i=1}^{n}w^{*}_{i}\phi_{i}(x) where w∗superscript𝑤w^{*} is the vector solving 3. After this approximation is found, the process II-A repeats. The current value function is reset and a new approximation is computed.

A fundamental question then is how to solve problem 3 from data. An approach is to perform what can be considered a stochastic gradient descent. Specifically, this in an iterative algorithm of the form

wk+1=wk−ε​∇^​J​(wk),k=0,1,…formulae-sequencesubscript𝑤𝑘1subscript𝑤𝑘𝜀^∇𝐽subscript𝑤𝑘𝑘01…w_{k+1}=w_{k}-\varepsilon\hat{\nabla}J(w_{k}),\;k=0,1,\ldots (4)

where ε>0𝜀0\varepsilon>0 is a stepsize, and the gradient is approximated from the data tuples as

∇^​J​(wk)=1T​∑t=0Tϕ​(xt)​(wkT​ϕ​(xt)−ct−γ​Vcurrent​(x+t)).^∇𝐽subscript𝑤𝑘1𝑇superscriptsubscript𝑡0𝑇italic-ϕsuperscript𝑥𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑤𝑘𝑇italic-ϕsuperscript𝑥𝑡superscript𝑐𝑡𝛾superscript𝑉currentsuperscriptsubscript𝑥𝑡\displaystyle\hat{\nabla}J(w_{k})=\frac{1}{T}\sum_{t=0}^{T}\phi(x^{t})\left(w_{k}^{T}\phi(x^{t})-c^{t}-\gamma V^{\text{current}}(x_{+}^{t})\right). (5)

In this expression, k𝑘k refers to iterations of the algorithm 4, while t𝑡t refers to identically distributed samples of state transitions and costs from the Markov Decision Process, and there are T𝑇T of them in total. It can be verified that this yields an unbiased estimate of the gradient of 3. After a large number of iterations N𝑁N of 4, which also means after drawing many data samples, and with an appropriate stepsize explained below, the iterate wNsubscript𝑤𝑁w_{N} will converge close to the optimal solution of the problem 3 which we denote as w∗superscript𝑤w^{*}.

Remark 1 (Relation to other Reinforcement Learning Approaches).

In this paper we illustrate how the above value function approximation in 3 can be performed with communication efficiency. This approximation then needs to be performed at each iteration of the value iteration algorithm II-A – see also Algorithm 1. The approach can also be extended to learn a Q-function approximation but this is not further discussed in this paper due to limited space. More broadly, these algorithms are variants of Projected Value Iteration [30, Vol. II, Ch. 6], and are behind many successful reinforcement learning approaches [32, 33]. These algorithms are attractive because under technical conditions they converge to a unique point.

II-B Communication-efficient reinforcement learning problem

Given the above modeling for a reinforcement learning task that needs to be solved, the communication problem is as follows. At each iteration k𝑘k, the server broadcasts the current weights wksubscript𝑤𝑘w_{k} to all agents. Then each agent i𝑖i collects T𝑇T local data samples identically distributed (across samples and across agents), computes a local stochastic gradient ∇^i​J​(wk)subscript^∇𝑖𝐽subscript𝑤𝑘\hat{\nabla}_{i}J(w_{k}) from the available local data using formula 5, and decides whether to transmit this gradient update over the communication network to the receiving server. The server updates the current vector of weights wksubscript𝑤𝑘w_{k} depending on the information received from different agents. For simplicity of exposition the case of two agents is considered and theoretically analyzed, and experiments with more agents are conducted numerically in Section V. This leads to the update rule at the server

wk+1={wk−ε​∇^1​J​(wk)if 1 transmitswk−ε​∇^2​J​(wk)if 2 transmitswk−ε2​(∇^1​J​(wk)+∇^2​J​(wk))if both transmitwkif no transmitssubscript𝑤𝑘1casessubscript𝑤𝑘𝜀subscript^∇1𝐽subscript𝑤𝑘if 1 transmitssubscript𝑤𝑘𝜀subscript^∇2𝐽subscript𝑤𝑘if 2 transmitssubscript𝑤𝑘𝜀2subscript^∇1𝐽subscript𝑤𝑘subscript^∇2𝐽subscript𝑤𝑘if both transmitsubscript𝑤𝑘if no transmitsw_{k+1}=\left\{\begin{array}[]{ll}w_{k}-\varepsilon\hat{\nabla}_{1}J(w_{k})&\text{if $1$ transmits}\\ w_{k}-\varepsilon\hat{\nabla}_{2}J(w_{k})&\text{if $2$ transmits}\\ w_{k}-\frac{\varepsilon}{2}(\hat{\nabla}_{1}J(w_{k})+\hat{\nabla}_{2}J(w_{k}))&\text{if both transmit}\\ w_{k}&\text{if no transmits}\end{array}\right. (6)

We further denote with αki∈{1,0}superscriptsubscript𝛼𝑘𝑖10\alpha_{k}^{i}\in\{1,0\} the decision for each agent i=1,2𝑖12i=1,2 to transmit or not.

At the next iteration k+1𝑘1k+1 a new set of data is collected at each agent, a new stochastic gradient direction ∇^i​J​(wk+1)subscript^∇𝑖𝐽subscript𝑤𝑘1\hat{\nabla}_{i}J(w_{k+1}) with respect to the new vector wk+1subscript𝑤𝑘1w_{k+1} is computed at each agent, and the process repeats until a final iteration N𝑁N. The algorithm is also described in Algorithm 1.

The aim will be to avoid sending updates all the time in order to limit the communication burden. Hence we consider the average communication cost during all iterations and across all agents as

1N​∑k=0N−1αk1+αk221𝑁superscriptsubscript𝑘0𝑁1superscriptsubscript𝛼𝑘1superscriptsubscript𝛼𝑘22\frac{1}{N}\sum_{k=0}^{N-1}\,\frac{\alpha_{k}^{1}+\alpha_{k}^{2}}{2} (7)

On the other hand, we want to understand the progress of learning, hence we also measure how well the final set of weights wNsubscript𝑤𝑁w_{N} solves 3, in other words we measure the cost function J​(wN)𝐽subscript𝑤𝑁J(w_{N}).

We note that since the data points at each iteration and at each agent are random, so are the constructed stochastic gradient directions, and so are the vectors wksubscript𝑤𝑘w_{k}, and so are the decisions αkisuperscriptsubscript𝛼𝑘𝑖\alpha_{k}^{i} of the agents to transmit. We propose then to measure the efficiency of the implementation on average over the data points collected. As a result, we establish the performance metric

𝔼data​[λ​∑k=0N−1αk1+αk22​N+J​(wN)]subscript𝔼datadelimited-[]𝜆superscriptsubscript𝑘0𝑁1superscriptsubscript𝛼𝑘1superscriptsubscript𝛼𝑘22𝑁𝐽subscript𝑤𝑁\mathbb{E}_{\text{data}}\left[\lambda\sum_{k=0}^{N-1}\,\frac{\alpha_{k}^{1}+\alpha_{k}^{2}}{2N}+J(w_{N})\right] (8)

Here λ>0𝜆0\lambda>0 is a tuning parameter that is used to either penalize communication or learning performance. It is worth emphasizing then that there are two expectations in this paper. One is the integral defined in the objective J​(w)𝐽𝑤J(w) in 3, and another is the expected performance of the implementation in 8 computed as an integral over tuples xt,ct,x+t+1superscript𝑥𝑡superscript𝑐𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑥𝑡1x^{t},c^{t},x_{+}^{t+1} – in total 2​N​T2𝑁𝑇2NT tuples over agents, iterations, and samples – and denoted as 𝔼datasubscript𝔼data\mathbb{E}_{\text{data}} to clarify the difference.

III Theoretical scheme for communication-efficient reinforcement learning

The approach is based on the notion of performance gain which can be thought as a measure of how informative are the data collected at each agent at each time step with respect to the reinforcement learning problem. The gain at agent i=1,2𝑖12i=1,2 can be calculated by measuring how much will the objective change if the agent sends the update. Whether this gain is negative or positive depends on the random direction of the update. The proposed approach then is to send a gradient update if the gain is large enough. Mathematically we write

αki={1if ​J​(wk−ε​∇^i​J​(wk))−J​(wk)≤−λρN−1−k0otherwisesuperscriptsubscript𝛼𝑘𝑖cases1if 𝐽subscript𝑤𝑘𝜀subscript^∇𝑖𝐽subscript𝑤𝑘𝐽subscript𝑤𝑘𝜆superscript𝜌𝑁1𝑘0otherwise\alpha_{k}^{i}=\left\{\begin{array}[]{ll}1&\text{if }J(w_{k}-\varepsilon\hat{\nabla}_{i}J(w_{k}))-J(w_{k})\leq-\frac{\lambda}{\rho^{N-1-k}}\\ 0&\text{otherwise}\end{array}\right. (9)

where the scalar parameter λ>0𝜆0\lambda>0 is the one defined in the performance criterion, and ρ∈(0,1)𝜌01\rho\in(0,1) is a parameter – whose impact is further discussed in the theoretical results below. Intuitively this approach saves up communication resources, because the updates will be infrequent. Moreover, the term at the right hand side, which measures how informative are the data at the current iteration, is decreasing (in absolute value) as the number of iterations grow. Hence, at the beginning only very informative updates are transmitted, while as learning progresses, less informative updates are transmitted as well.

Assumption 1.

The n×n𝑛𝑛n\times n symmetric matrix 𝔼d​ϕ​(x)​ϕ​(x)Tsubscript𝔼𝑑italic-ϕ𝑥italic-ϕsuperscript𝑥𝑇\mathbb{E}_{d}\phi(x)\phi(x)^{T} is positive definite.

This assumption guarantees the solution to the main problem 3 is unique.

Assumption 2.

The step size ε>0𝜀0\varepsilon>0 in 6 satisfies

|1−2​ε​λi​(𝔼d​ϕ​(x)​ϕ​(x)T)|<112𝜀subscript𝜆𝑖subscript𝔼𝑑italic-ϕ𝑥italic-ϕsuperscript𝑥𝑇1\left|1-2\varepsilon\lambda_{i}(\mathbb{E}_{d}\phi(x)\phi(x)^{T})\right|<1 (10)

for all eigenvalues of the matrix at the right hand side.

This assumption guarantees the step size is small enough so that convergence, even without communication constraints, is satisfied. A sufficient condition is ε<2/λmax𝜀2subscript𝜆\varepsilon<2/\lambda_{\max} where λmaxsubscript𝜆\lambda_{\max} is the largest eigenvalue of the above matrix. Assumption 1 guarantees that 10 can be met.

Assumption 3.

The parameter ρ𝜌\rho in 9 satisfies

ρ≥maxi(1−2ελi(𝔼dϕ(x)ϕ(x)T))2\rho\geq\max_{i}(1-2\varepsilon\lambda_{i}(\mathbb{E}_{d}\phi(x)\phi(x)^{T}))^{2} (11)

for all eigenvalues of the matrix at the right hand side.

This assumption states that measuring the informativeness of the data should decrease at a sufficiently slow rate. Assumptions 2 and 3 together guarantee that ρ<1𝜌1\rho<1 is a possible choice.

The main theoretical result of this paper is established next.

Theorem 1 (Communication-Efficient Value Function Approximation).

Consider the optimization problem defined in 3. Consider the update rule in 6. Suppose ∇^i​J​(wk),i=1,2,formulae-sequencesubscript^∇𝑖𝐽subscript𝑤𝑘𝑖12\hat{\nabla}_{i}J(w_{k}),i=1,2, are independent random variables with mean equal to ∇J​(wk)∇𝐽subscript𝑤𝑘\nabla J(w_{k}) and covariance G𝐺G at each iteration k𝑘k. Consider the communication strategy in 9 with a fixed number of iterations N𝑁N. Let Assumptions 1-3 hold. Then we have that

𝔼data​[λ​∑k=0N−1αk1+αk22​N+J​(wN)]≤λ+J​(w∗)subscript𝔼datadelimited-[]𝜆superscriptsubscript𝑘0𝑁1superscriptsubscript𝛼𝑘1superscriptsubscript𝛼𝑘22𝑁𝐽subscript𝑤𝑁𝜆𝐽superscript𝑤\displaystyle\mathbb{E}_{\text{data}}\left[\lambda\sum_{k=0}^{N-1}\frac{\alpha_{k}^{1}+\alpha_{k}^{2}}{2N}+J(w_{N})\right]\leq\lambda+J(w^{*})
+ρN​[J​(w0)−J​(w∗)]+1−ρN1−ρ​ε2​Tr​(𝔼d​ϕ​(x)​ϕ​(x)T​G)superscript𝜌𝑁delimited-[]𝐽subscript𝑤0𝐽superscript𝑤1superscript𝜌𝑁1𝜌superscript𝜀2Trsubscript𝔼𝑑italic-ϕ𝑥italic-ϕsuperscript𝑥𝑇𝐺\displaystyle+\rho^{N}[J(w_{0})-J(w^{*})]+\frac{1-\rho^{N}}{1-\rho}\varepsilon^{2}\text{Tr}(\mathbb{E}_{d}\phi(x)\phi(x)^{T}G) (12)

where w∗superscript𝑤w^{*} is the optimal solution of 3 and the expectation is with respect to the data collected until iteration N𝑁N.

We have the following observations. The terms on the right hand side of 1 measure the suboptimality of learning, including the terms that have to do with the poor initialization J​(w0)−J​(w∗)𝐽subscript𝑤0𝐽superscript𝑤J(w_{0})-J(w^{*}) and the noise of the gradients captured by the matrix G𝐺G. As the number of iterations N𝑁N grows, the impact of the former is diminished, and only the latter remains. This expression also suggests that ideally one would pick the parameter ρ𝜌\rho to be the minimum allowed by the above Assumption 3.

The theorem characterizes the tradeoff between communication and learning. By increasing the parameter λ𝜆\lambda, there is a higher penalty for communicating, and as a result, the agents communicate less often — see following remark. As a consequence, learning performance will be impacted. But the above theorem guarantees by design that there will be a graceful compromise between communication performance and learning – the left hand side 1 cannot be arbitrarily poor.

It is worth noting that, essentially, from the right hand side of 1, the theorem states that the aggregate performance will be better than just having one agent only and transmitting all the time. It is possible to extend the analysis to get bounds sharper than 1, which will be the topic of future work.

Remark 2.

In Theorem 1 we assumed for simplicity that the stochastic gradients have bounded covariances that are constant over time. In reality for the problem above the covariance of the stochastic gradient in 5 will depend on the current iterate wksubscript𝑤𝑘w_{k}, but our choice can be justified. For example we can add a projection to a bounded set ‖wk‖<Mnormsubscript𝑤𝑘𝑀\|w_{k}\|<M in the algorithm, so we only search over this restricted set of weights, resulting in bounded gradient noise covariances.

Remark 3 (Analysis over mutiple iterations).

The above theoretical analysis is performed for one iteration of Alg. 1 (lines 5-9). As a result, at each iteration communication-efficiency is guaranteed. After many iterations, the algorithm will converge to a neighborhood of the desired set of weights w𝑤w, i.e., the value function approximation. This analysis will be explored in future work.

IV Practical scheme for communication-efficient reinforcement learning

Despite the above guarantee, implementing the theoretical communication scheme in 9 would be practically impossible because it requires information that is not known. Specifically it would require for every agent to know the Markov Decision Process and the data distribution in order to compute the actual performance gain. Since these are unknown, one approach is to estimate the performance gain from the data. In particular, since the objective function is quadratic, we can write the performance gain as

J​(wk−ε​∇^i​J​(wk))−J​(wk)=−ε​∇^i​J​(wk)T​∇J​(wk)𝐽subscript𝑤𝑘𝜀subscript^∇𝑖𝐽subscript𝑤𝑘𝐽subscript𝑤𝑘𝜀subscript^∇𝑖𝐽superscriptsubscript𝑤𝑘𝑇∇𝐽subscript𝑤𝑘\displaystyle J\left(w_{k}-\varepsilon\hat{\nabla}_{i}J(w_{k})\right)-J(w_{k})=-\varepsilon\hat{\nabla}_{i}J(w_{k})^{T}\nabla J(w_{k})
+12​ε2​∇^i​J​(wk)T​∇2J​(wk)​∇^i​J​(wk)12superscript𝜀2subscript^∇𝑖𝐽superscriptsubscript𝑤𝑘𝑇superscript∇2𝐽subscript𝑤𝑘subscript^∇𝑖𝐽subscript𝑤𝑘\displaystyle+\frac{1}{2}\varepsilon^{2}\hat{\nabla}_{i}J(w_{k})^{T}\nabla^{2}J(w_{k})\hat{\nabla}_{i}J(w_{k}) (13)

This is a quadratic function of the stochastic gradient ∇^i​J​(wk)subscript^∇𝑖𝐽subscript𝑤𝑘\hat{\nabla}_{i}J(w_{k}). Then we can approximate the gradient and the Hessian at each agent as

∇J​(wk)≈∇^i​J​(wk)∇𝐽subscript𝑤𝑘subscript^∇𝑖𝐽subscript𝑤𝑘\displaystyle\nabla J(w_{k})\approx\hat{\nabla}_{i}J(w_{k})
∇2J​(wk)≈1T​∑t=0Tϕ​(xt)​ϕ​(xt)Tsuperscript∇2𝐽subscript𝑤𝑘1𝑇superscriptsubscript𝑡0𝑇italic-ϕsuperscript𝑥𝑡italic-ϕsuperscriptsuperscript𝑥𝑡𝑇\displaystyle\nabla^{2}J(w_{k})\approx\frac{1}{T}\sum_{t=0}^{T}\phi(x^{t})\phi(x^{t})^{T} (14)

Hence, using the expression for the information gain in IV, we can approximate the gain at agent i=1,2𝑖12i=1,2 as222Overall at each agent these computations require O​(T​n)𝑂𝑇𝑛O(Tn) operations hence are scalable.

J​(wk−ε​∇^i​J​(wk))−J​(wk)≈𝐽subscript𝑤𝑘𝜀subscript^∇𝑖𝐽subscript𝑤𝑘𝐽subscript𝑤𝑘absent\displaystyle J\left(w_{k}-\varepsilon\hat{\nabla}_{i}J(w_{k})\right)-J(w_{k})\approx
−∇^i​J​(wk)T​[I−ε​12​1T​∑t=0Tϕ​(xt)​ϕ​(xt)T]​∇^i​J​(wk)Tsubscript^∇𝑖𝐽superscriptsubscript𝑤𝑘𝑇delimited-[]𝐼𝜀121𝑇superscriptsubscript𝑡0𝑇italic-ϕsuperscript𝑥𝑡italic-ϕsuperscriptsuperscript𝑥𝑡𝑇subscript^∇𝑖𝐽superscriptsubscript𝑤𝑘𝑇\displaystyle-\hat{\nabla}_{i}J(w_{k})^{T}\left[I-\varepsilon\frac{1}{2}\frac{1}{T}\sum_{t=0}^{T}\phi(x^{t})\phi(x^{t})^{T}\right]\hat{\nabla}_{i}J(w_{k})^{T} (15)

It is important to emphasize that this is no longer a simple quadratic function of the stochastic gradient but a more complicated function - we note that the data appear both in the stochastic gradients as well as in the matrix in the middle. This approximate value of the gain may take again positive or negative values but it induces an approximation error/bias.

As a result, we can implement the communication decision in 9 with the approximation in IV. In this case we no longer have the performance guarantee in Theorem 1. In numerical evaluations however we see that despite the bias this mechanism performs very well.

Remark 4.

Another intuitive approach to evaluate the informativeness of the data is to assume that the performance gain IV is large when the stochastic gradient has a large norm ‖∇^i​J​(wk)‖normsubscript^∇𝑖𝐽subscript𝑤𝑘\|\hat{\nabla}_{i}J(w_{k})\| at an agent. However, recent work [15, 16] has demonstrated that this approach is not necessarily communication-efficient. A different perspective is followed by [17]. When agents do not update their gradients at the server, the server keeps a memory of past received gradients and uses them for gradient descent in 6. The advantage of the present approach is that it introduces an explicit communication-learning tradeoff that can be controlled by the parameter λ𝜆\lambda. Technically, the approach [17] is developed for policy gradient methods, while here the approach is developed for value-function-based approaches.

V Numerical results

We consider first a grid exploration example (Fig. 2) which is a finite state Markov Decision Process with state space X𝑋X. An agent can move in four directions subject to the boundary constraints, while at the top part of the grid there is a 50% uncertainty in transitions to the right because of disturbances. The objective function is the total undiscounted (γ=1𝛾1\gamma=1) time it takes to reach a desired goal location G. We collect measurements from multiple agents following the policy that randomizes over all actions at each state.

We perform one iteration of Algorithm 1 following II-A where the initial value function is chosen randomly. In order to learn the exact value function we take the basis functions/features to be the indicators ϕ​(1)=[1,0,…,0]T,ϕ​(2)=[0,1,0,…,0]Tformulae-sequenceitalic-ϕ1superscript10…0𝑇italic-ϕ2superscript010…0𝑇\phi(1)=[1,0,\ldots,0]^{T},\phi(2)=[0,1,0,\ldots,0]^{T}, etc in 2. We suppose each agent has few data tuples T=10𝑇10T=10 in every iteration, as described in Section II, chosen from a uniform distribution d𝑑d on this finite state space, and we take the stepsize to be ε=1𝜀1\varepsilon=1. We implement the theoretical approach 9 and the practical approach using IV. We pick the parameter ρ𝜌\rho to be close to its smallest value allowed by Assumption 3. For varying values of the parameter λ𝜆\lambda we empirically compute the average communication rate 7, and the average final learning performance J​(wN)𝐽subscript𝑤𝑁J(w_{N}) as defined in 3. The achieved tradeoff between the two is shown in Fig. 2. As a comparison, we also include the results when agents randomly decide whether the transmit their gradients or not, leading to an inefficient outcome.

For the theoretical algorithm 9, we observe that a very high communication efficiency can be achieved, i.e., by transmitting only a fraction of the time it is possible to find very good solutions to the value function approximation problem, hence achieving a good communication-learning tradeoff. For the practical approach using IV of course the learning loss is higher due to the bias introduced, but we also clearly observe a very good tradeoff between all agents communicating all the time versus scarce communications only when necessary.

Then for a more complicated scenario we consider a continuous (uncountable) state space problem X=ℝ2𝑋superscriptℝ2X={\mathbb{R}}^{2}. State transitions are given by a stochastic linear dynamical system x+=A​x+wsubscript𝑥𝐴𝑥𝑤x_{+}=Ax+w, with A=[0.8−0.20.11]𝐴delimited-[]0.80.20.11A=\left[\begin{array}[]{cc}0.8&-0.2\\ 0.1&1\end{array}\right], where w𝑤w is a zero-mean Gaussian noise variable with covariance 0.10.10.1. We also consider a quadratic cost c​(x)=‖x‖2𝑐𝑥superscriptnorm𝑥2c(x)=\|x\|^{2} and a discount factor γ=0.9𝛾0.9\gamma=0.9. We want to perform one value iteration following II-A where the initial value function is chosen randomly. We would like to approximate the updated value function per 2 as a linear combination of polynomial functions of the states with maximum degree 2 – that is ϕ​(x)=[x12,x22,x1​x2,x1,x2,1]T∈ℝ6italic-ϕ𝑥superscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝑥12superscriptsubscript𝑥22subscript𝑥1subscript𝑥2subscript𝑥1subscript𝑥21𝑇superscriptℝ6\phi(x)=[x_{1}^{2},x_{2}^{2},x_{1}x_{2},x_{1},x_{2},1]^{T}\in{\mathbb{R}}^{6} – and we are searching for a vector of weights w∈ℝ6𝑤superscriptℝ6w\in{\mathbb{R}}^{6}. We suppose each agent has at every iteration T=103𝑇superscript103T=10^{3} data tuples, as described in Section II, chosen from a uniform distribution d𝑑d on the space [0,1]2superscript012[0,1]^{2}. We take the stepsize to be ε=1𝜀1\varepsilon=1 and the parameter ρ=0.999𝜌0.999\rho=0.999. As expected when learning value functions on continuous state space, in this case we need many more iterations and a larger amount of data, in the order of 108superscript10810^{8} data tuples.

We implement the practical communication algorithm with IV. Fig. 3 shows the evolution of weights for a large penalty λ𝜆\lambda on communication rate. The figure shows that at the beginning no communication takes place because not very high informative gradients are found, while more communication takes place as learning progresses. Fig. 3 shows the same setup with a smaller penalty λ𝜆\lambda on communication, and we observe higher communication rate and faster learning of the weights. These observations verify the findings of Theorem 1. Finally Fig. 3 shows the same setup but with a larger number of agents, 10 instead of 2. We observe that learning happens faster, with almost the same amount of average communication rate. This observation is not yet studied theoretically here and will be explored in future work.

VI Concluding remarks

This paper examines the problem of solving reinforcement learning tasks over a network. To exploit the informativeness of the data, the notion of performance gain is explored and is shown numerically how this can be approximated from the data without further model knowledge. The approach is supported theoretically and numerically. Ongoing work explores the use of the approach in more complex networks and reinforcement learning algorithms.

Within this proof for brevity we denote the stochastic gradients and the performance gains as

𝔼​[12​λk​(αk1+αk2)+J​(wk+1)|wk]𝔼delimited-[]12subscript𝜆𝑘superscriptsubscript𝛼𝑘1superscriptsubscript𝛼𝑘2conditional𝐽subscript𝑤𝑘1subscript𝑤𝑘\displaystyle\mathbb{E}[\frac{1}{2}\lambda_{k}(\alpha_{k}^{1}+\alpha_{k}^{2})+J(w_{k+1}){\,\big{|}\,}w_{k}] ≤λk+𝔼​[J​(wk−ε​gki)|wk]absentsubscript𝜆𝑘𝔼delimited-[]conditional𝐽subscript𝑤𝑘𝜀superscriptsubscript𝑔𝑘𝑖subscript𝑤𝑘\displaystyle\leq\lambda_{k}+\mathbb{E}[J(w_{k}-\varepsilon g_{k}^{i}){\,\big{|}\,}w_{k}] (28)

Then given the fact that the function J​(w)𝐽𝑤J(w) in 3 is quadratic, i.e., can be written in the form

J​(w)=(w−w∗)T​𝔼d​ϕ​(w−w∗)+J​(w∗)𝐽𝑤superscript𝑤superscript𝑤𝑇subscript𝔼𝑑italic-ϕ𝑤superscript𝑤𝐽superscript𝑤J(w)=(w-w^{*})^{T}\mathbb{E}_{d}\phi(w-w^{*})+J(w^{*}) (29)

𝔼​[(wk−ε​gki−w∗)​Φ​(wk−ε​gki−w∗)]+J​(w∗)𝔼delimited-[]subscript𝑤𝑘𝜀superscriptsubscript𝑔𝑘𝑖superscript𝑤Φsubscript𝑤𝑘𝜀superscriptsubscript𝑔𝑘𝑖superscript𝑤𝐽superscript𝑤\displaystyle\mathbb{E}[(w_{k}-\varepsilon g_{k}^{i}-w^{*})\Phi(w_{k}-\varepsilon g_{k}^{i}-w^{*})]+J(w^{*})
=(wk−w∗)T​(I−2​ε​Φ)T​Φ​(I−2​ε​Φ)​(wk−w∗)absentsuperscriptsubscript𝑤𝑘superscript𝑤𝑇superscript𝐼2𝜀Φ𝑇Φ𝐼2𝜀Φsubscript𝑤𝑘superscript𝑤\displaystyle=(w_{k}-w^{*})^{T}(I-2\varepsilon\Phi)^{T}\Phi(I-2\varepsilon\Phi)(w_{k}-w^{*})
+ε2​Tr​(Φ​G)+J​(w∗)superscript𝜀2TrΦ𝐺𝐽superscript𝑤\displaystyle+\varepsilon^{2}\text{Tr}(\Phi G)+J(w^{*}) (30)

Then by Assumption 3 we can bound

𝔼[J(wk−εgk)\displaystyle\mathbb{E}[J(w_{k}-\varepsilon g_{k}) |wk]≤ρJ(wk)+ε2Tr(ΦG)+(1−ρ)J(w∗)\displaystyle{\,\big{|}\,}w_{k}]\leq\rho J(w_{k})+\varepsilon^{2}\text{Tr}(\Phi G)+(1-\rho)J(w^{*}) (31)

Substituting this in 28 we get,

𝔼​[λk​αk1+αk22+J​(wk+1)|wk]≤λk+ρ​J​(wk)𝔼delimited-[]subscript𝜆𝑘superscriptsubscript𝛼𝑘1superscriptsubscript𝛼𝑘22conditional𝐽subscript𝑤𝑘1subscript𝑤𝑘subscript𝜆𝑘𝜌𝐽subscript𝑤𝑘\displaystyle\mathbb{E}[\lambda_{k}\frac{\alpha_{k}^{1}+\alpha_{k}^{2}}{2}+J(w_{k+1}){\,\big{|}\,}w_{k}]\leq\lambda_{k}+\rho J(w_{k}) (32)
+ε2​Tr​(Φ​G)+(1−ρ)​J​(w∗)superscript𝜀2TrΦ𝐺1𝜌𝐽superscript𝑤\displaystyle+\varepsilon^{2}\text{Tr}(\Phi G)+(1-\rho)J(w^{*}) (33)

Then for time-varying parameter λk=λρN−k−1​Nsubscript𝜆𝑘𝜆superscript𝜌𝑁𝑘1𝑁\lambda_{k}=\frac{\lambda}{\rho^{N-k-1}N} we get

and complete the desired result 1. ∎

-B Proof of 27

Within this proof we drop the iteration index k𝑘k. Let us denote by F​(g)𝐹𝑔F(g) the distribution of the stochastic gradient g:=∇^​J​(wk)assign𝑔^∇𝐽subscript𝑤𝑘g:=\hat{\nabla}J(w_{k}) at any agent. Then we can rewrite 27 as

∫α​(g)​J​(w−ε​g)​𝑑F​(g)≤∫α​(g)​𝑑F​(g)​∫J​(w−ε​g)​𝑑F​(g)𝛼𝑔𝐽𝑤𝜀𝑔differential-d𝐹𝑔𝛼𝑔differential-d𝐹𝑔𝐽𝑤𝜀𝑔differential-d𝐹𝑔\int\alpha(g)J(w-\varepsilon g)dF(g)\leq\int\alpha(g)dF(g)\int J(w-\varepsilon g)dF(g) (38)

However, by definition of the communication rule 9 we have that α​(g)=1𝛼𝑔1\alpha(g)=1 only when J​(w−ε​g)≤J​(w)−λ𝐽𝑤𝜀𝑔𝐽𝑤𝜆J(w-\varepsilon g)\leq J(w)-\lambda and zero otherwise. Let us define this set of values S={g∈ℝn:J​(w−ε​g)≤J​(w)−λ}𝑆conditional-set𝑔superscriptℝ𝑛𝐽𝑤𝜀𝑔𝐽𝑤𝜆S=\{g\in{\mathbb{R}}^{n}:J(w-\varepsilon g)\leq J(w)-\lambda\}, which is allowed to be an empty set too. Then 27 is equivalent to

∫SJ​(w−ε​g)​𝑑F​(g)≤subscript𝑆𝐽𝑤𝜀𝑔differential-d𝐹𝑔absent\displaystyle\int_{S}J(w-\varepsilon g)dF(g)\leq
∫S𝑑F​(g)​[∫SJ​(w−ε​g)​𝑑F​(g)+∫ScJ​(w−ε​g)​𝑑F​(g)]subscript𝑆differential-d𝐹𝑔delimited-[]subscript𝑆𝐽𝑤𝜀𝑔differential-d𝐹𝑔subscriptsuperscript𝑆𝑐𝐽𝑤𝜀𝑔differential-d𝐹𝑔\displaystyle\int_{S}dF(g)\left[\int_{S}J(w-\varepsilon g)dF(g)+\int_{S^{c}}J(w-\varepsilon g)dF(g)\right] (39)

which is equivalent to

∫Sc𝑑F​(g)​∫SJ​(w−ε​g)​𝑑F​(g)≤∫S𝑑F​(g)​∫ScJ​(w−ε​g)​𝑑F​(g)subscriptsuperscript𝑆𝑐differential-d𝐹𝑔subscript𝑆𝐽𝑤𝜀𝑔differential-d𝐹𝑔subscript𝑆differential-d𝐹𝑔subscriptsuperscript𝑆𝑐𝐽𝑤𝜀𝑔differential-d𝐹𝑔\displaystyle\int_{S^{c}}dF(g)\int_{S}J(w-\varepsilon g)dF(g)\leq\int_{S}dF(g)\int_{S^{c}}J(w-\varepsilon g)dF(g) (40)

We can bound the left hand side because we can bound J​(w−ε​g)𝐽𝑤𝜀𝑔J(w-\varepsilon g) point wise on the set S𝑆S as

∫Sc𝑑F​(g)​∫SJ​(w−ε​g)​𝑑F​(g)≤∫Sc𝑑F​(g)​∫S𝑑F​(g)​[J​(w)−λ]subscriptsuperscript𝑆𝑐differential-d𝐹𝑔subscript𝑆𝐽𝑤𝜀𝑔differential-d𝐹𝑔subscriptsuperscript𝑆𝑐differential-d𝐹𝑔subscript𝑆differential-d𝐹𝑔delimited-[]𝐽𝑤𝜆\displaystyle\int_{S^{c}}dF(g)\int_{S}J(w-\varepsilon g)dF(g)\leq\int_{S^{c}}dF(g)\int_{S}dF(g)\;[J(w)-\lambda] (41)

Further we can bound the right hand side of 40 as

∫S𝑑F​(g)​∫ScJ​(w−ε​g)​𝑑F​(g)≥∫S𝑑F​(g)​∫Sc𝑑F​(g)​[J​(w)−λ]subscript𝑆differential-d𝐹𝑔subscriptsuperscript𝑆𝑐𝐽𝑤𝜀𝑔differential-d𝐹𝑔subscript𝑆differential-d𝐹𝑔subscriptsuperscript𝑆𝑐differential-d𝐹𝑔delimited-[]𝐽𝑤𝜆\displaystyle\int_{S}dF(g)\int_{S^{c}}J(w-\varepsilon g)dF(g)\geq\int_{S}dF(g)\int_{S^{c}}dF(g)\;[J(w)-\lambda] (42)

Combining 41 and 42 we verify 40 and conclude the proof.
